all.title: Unstructured Data Objects
all.text: Data without a predefined structure, making them difficult to manage conventionally...
all.longText: Data without a predefined structure, making them difficult to manage conventionally. Examples include text documents, images, audio, video, social media posts, and emails.

all.title: Vector
all.text: A quantity having both magnitude and direction represented by an array of numerical values...
all.longText: A quantity having both magnitude and direction represented by an array of numerical values.

all.title: Vector Embedding
all.text: Numerical representations of objects, such as words or images, in a vector space...
all.longText: Numerical representations of objects, such as words or images, in a vector space. These representations capture semantic relationships and are used in machine-learning tasks.

all.title: Embeddings Model
all.text: An algorithm or model that transforms objects (like words) into vector embeddings...
all.longText: An algorithm or model that transforms objects (like words) into vector embeddings. This enables capturing contextual and semantic information.

all.title: Sparse Vectors
all.text: Sparse embeddings are generated from algorithms like BM25 and SPLADE...
all.longText: Sparse vectors are often high-dimensional with many zeros. Sparse embeddings are generated from algorithms like BM25 and SPLADE. These algorithms are used in keyword-based search to represent text documents.

all.title: Dense Vectors
all.text: In contrast to sparse vectors, dense vectors contain mostly non-zero values and are generated from machine learning models like GloVe and Transformers...
all.longText: In contrast to sparse vectors, dense vectors contain mostly non-zero values and are generated from machine learning models like GloVe and Transformers. These vectors capture the semantic meaning of text and are used in vector search techniques.

all.title: BM25/BM25F
all.text: BM25 is a ranking function used by search engines to estimate the relevance of documents to a given search query. It is part of the family of probabilistic information retrieval models...
all.longText: BM25 is a ranking function used by search engines to estimate the relevance of documents to a given search query. It is part of the family of probabilistic information retrieval models. BM25F is a variant of BM25 that can handle fields with different weights, such as title and body in documents.

all.title: Alpha Parameter
all.text: This is an optional parameter in hybrid search queries that determines the weighting of each search algorithm during the re-ranking process...
all.longText: This is an optional parameter in hybrid search queries that determines the weighting of each search algorithm during the re-ranking process. An alpha value of 0 gives full weight to the sparse vector (BM25), 1 gives full weight to the dense vector, and 0.5 gives equal weight to both.

all.title: Fusion Algorithm
all.text: In hybrid search, the fusion algorithm combines results from keyword and vector searches into a final list of ranked search results...
all.longText: In hybrid search, the fusion algorithm combines results from keyword and vector searches into a final list of ranked search results. A popular fusion algorithm is called reciprocal ranked fusion, which uses the sum of the inverse of the position of the results. There are multiple types of fusion algorithms. Weaviate supports reciprocal rank fusion and relative score fusion.

all.title: Hierarchical Graph Structure
all.text: HNSW utilizes a multi-layered graph structure where each layer is a graph of the data points. The top layers contain fewer points with long-range connections...
all.longText: HNSW utilizes a multi-layered graph structure where each layer is a graph of the data points. The top layers contain fewer points with long-range connections, and as you go down the layers, the number of points increases, and the connections become more local. This hierarchical structure allows for efficient navigation during search queries.

all.title: ANN - Approximate Nearest Neighbor
all.text: ANN algorithms calculate the approximate nearest neighbors to a query, as opposed to kNN algorithms, which calculate the true nearest neighbors...
all.longText: ANN algorithms calculate the approximate nearest neighbors to a query, as opposed to kNN algorithms, which calculate the true nearest neighbors. ANN algorithms enable the quick and efficient identification of the closest data points at scale. This makes ANN suitable for big data where speed matters more than perfect accuracy.

all.title: Layered Navigation
all.text: During a search, HNSW starts at the topmost layer and makes 'big jumps' across the graph to quickly move closer to the target region...
all.longText: During a search, HNSW starts at the topmost layer and makes 'big jumps' across the graph to quickly move closer to the target region. As it moves down the layers, the search becomes more refined, with smaller, more local jumps until the nearest neighbors are identified in the bottom layer.

all.title: Graph-Based Index
all.text: HNSW is a graph-based indexing technique, meaning that it organizes the data points in a graph structure rather than traditional tree-based or hash-based structures...
all.longText: HNSW is a graph-based indexing technique, meaning that it organizes the data points in a graph structure rather than traditional tree-based or hash-based structures. This graph-based approach is key to its performance in high-dimensional vector space searches.

all.title: Graph-Based Index
all.text: A vector index is a type of data structure for efficiently storing high-dimensional vector data generated by machine learning models. Its main purpose is facilitating quick and accurate similarity searches...
all.longText: A vector index is a type of data structure for efficiently storing high-dimensional vector data generated by machine learning models. Its main purpose is facilitating quick and accurate similarity searches, using algorithms like trees or hashing to reduce complexity in high-dimensional spaces.

all.title: Cross Modal Reasoning
all.text: Cross-modal reasoning refers to the ability to make connections by integrating information from different modalities or sources including text, images, audio and video...
all.longText: Cross-modal reasoning refers to the ability to make connections by integrating information from different modalities or sources including text, images, audio and video. It involves leveraging knowledge from one modality to understand or reason about data from another modality.

all.title: Multimodal Embeddings Models
all.text: Multimodal Embeddings Models produce a joint embedding space for multimodal data that understands text, images, audio and more...
all.longText: Multimodal Embeddings Models produce a joint embedding space for multimodal data that understands text, images, audio and more. Objects that are similar are closer together and dissimilar objects are farther apart, this means that the model preserves semantic similarity within and across modalities.

all.title: Multimodal Contrastive Finetuning
all.text: Multimodal Embeddings Models produce a joint embedding space for multimodal data that understands text, images, audio and more...
all.longText: Multimodal Embeddings Models produce a joint embedding space for multimodal data that understands text, images, audio and more. Objects that are similar are closer together and dissimilar objects are farther apart, this means that the model preserves semantic similarity within and across modalities.

all.title: Any-to-any Search
all.text: In any-to-any search we can pass in as a query any modality the model understands and use it to perform vector similarity search...
all.longText: In any-to-any search we can pass in as a query any modality the model understands and use it to perform vector similarity search in multimodal embedding space, getting back objects of any other modality that are similar in concept.

all.title: Multimodal RAG
all.text: Multimodal RAG involves retrieving from a multimodal knowledge base and then generation using a large multimodal model by...
all.longText: Multimodal RAG involves retrieving from a multimodal knowledge base and then generation using a large multimodal model by generating text or images grounded in the retrieved context, which can include images, text, audio, and other modalities.
